awd_titl_txt: Vectorially-Coupled Reaction Networks in Low-Dimensional Nanofluidic Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Reactions are the central events of chemistry and controlling their behavior and the locations where they occur is at the heart of chemical measurements and making new chemicals. Ideally, scientists want to design reactions so they occur rapidly, make efficient use of all the chemical participants, employ inexpensive chemicals and environmentally friendly conditions, and produce easily-isolated chemical products. In nature, such as in biological cells, these stringent objectives are achieved by spatially-organized reaction networks. Dr. Paul Bohn's research team at the University of Notre Dame mimics nature by designing and developing networks of reactions whose behavior is controlled by electrical stimulus and whose location is defined by the size of the reaction vessel. In their work with electron-transfer reactions, they carefully build specially-designed structures from nanometer-sized materials, whose nature and placement leads to particular, well-defined, and highly efficient reactions occurring in specific locations. Furthermore, electrical control of the location-specific reactions and movement of nearby liquid allows for shuttling of chemical products from one reaction site to another one downstream, where they are used as the chemical starting materials for another defined reaction process. All the reactions are sped up using enzymes, nature's chemical reaction catalysts.  The Bohn team is developing an understanding of how electrical voltages can be applied to control the activity of catalysts. The research efforts are integrated with new education and training programs that cut across disciplinary lines within the University of Notre Dame and combine talents from multiple universities. In the process, these activities address specific NSF goals including development of a diverse, globally competitive science-technology-engineering-mathematics workforce; increased partnerships between academia and industry; and improved economic competitiveness.

The principal goal of this project supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program and partial co-funding from the Molecular Separations, Electrochemical Systems, and Process Systems, Reaction Engineering and Molecular Thermodynamics Programs at NSF is to develop networks of spatially-organized redox reactions which can be controlled by electrical signals to manage transport, dictate reactivity, and isolate products. The overall goal is addressed by developing control over delivery of reactant molecules and particles to a reactive site as well as control over reactivity, within zero- and one-dimensional electrochemical nanostructures.  The team also combines these nanostructures to develop full three-dimensional control over cascade reactions to produce vectorially-controlled reaction networks (VCRNs). The first objective is the development of high-precision nanoscale architectures to support VCRNs by simultaneous control over transport and reactivity using both metal-insulator multilayer stack-based nanopores and hierarchically-organized assemblies. The second objective explores ways in which electrochemical potential can be used to control activity of enzymes bound to one of the electrodes. Using horseradish peroxidase, HRP, as a model oxidoreductase enzyme, the intrinsic reactivity of the electrode-bound enzyme is followed using a fluorogenic redox reaction that converts a non-fluorescent reactant into fluorescent product within the ultrahigh sensitivity environment of an electrochemical zero-mode waveguide. These capabilities are being combined and tested using a set of stringent single enzyme kinetics experiments, in which the HRP is moved among the available locations and tested for intrinsic reactivity when coupled to an electrochemical potential control signal. The ultimate goal of this work is to leverage control of single reaction events to create a preparative scale capability for VCRNs. To test this capability, two-enzyme electrochemically-modulated reaction systems are being coupled to individual reactions in a spatially coordinated manner and used to deliver the reaction products to a downstream collection point. This project has impact outside the principal discipline of chemical analysis, especially in the general area of cascade reactions - powerful constructs in chemical synthesis that are used, for example, in enzymatic biofuel cells to capture the full electrochemical reducing power of fuel sources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

por.por_cntn:
The central goal of the work on this project was to develop networks of spatially-organized redox reactions, with the goal of controlling them with electrical signals to manage transport of reactants and products, dictate reactivity, and isolate products. The overall goal was addressed by developing: (a) control over delivery of reactant molecules and particles to a reactive site; (b) control over reactivity, within zero-dimensional and one-dimensional electrochemical nanostructures; and (c) combining these to develop full three-dimensional control over cascade reactions, i.e., tightly coupled reactions in which the product from the first (upstream) reaction is the reactant for a second (downstream) reaction. Accomplishing this goal produced vectorially-controlled reaction networks.

 

The first objective was to develop architectures that could be used to control the movement of reaction components at the nanoscale. To address this challenge, we constructed hierarchically organized ion-gates from pH-responsive block copolymer membranes. These structures were designed to control the access of ions to dual-ring embedded nanopore electrode arrays to achieve smart ion-transport control in response to pH-changes. They were used to pass ions of interest to regions of the structure containing electrodes for amplified electrochemical detection. These devices also were found to exhibit dual-gating characteristics using electrowetting - a process in which a potential applied across the block copolymer nanochannels controls the wetting characteristics of the channel controls the ability of aqueous solutions to pass through it.. To understand this process, we measured current-time behavior as a function of potential. At potentials exceeding 2.0 V, a current burst was observed with strong fluctuations - stochastic behavior indicative of electric-field-induced wetting/dewetting.

 

Another objective of the project was to optically interrogate the chemistry being controlled in the small pores. Thus, we developed electrochemical zero-mode waveguides (E-ZMWs), a new kind of hybrid nanostructure capable of controlling the redox environment and measuring the fluorescence of carefully chosen reporter species. We showed that electrochemical control of proton production in ultrasmall volume nanopores permits study of acid-base chemistry down to the limit where only the pore contains only a single ion. We also used the E-ZMWs to examine the behavior of single molecules of the enzyme glutathione reductase (GR), both immobilized to electrode surfaces and freely-diffusing. To address immobilized enzymes, we added a top electrode to introduce hydrogen peroxide, H2O2, to control the ratio of oxidized to reduced glutathione (a member of a major redox homeostasis system). Holding the bottom electrode negative kept GR flavins in the non-fluorescent form, FADH2. Enzymatic reactions were monitored by the transient production of oxidized (fluorescent) FAD, which was then quickly converted back to the reduced FADH2, resulting in fluorescence transients, the frequency of which was used to characterize single molecule reaction dynamics in the E-ZMW. To address freely-diffusing GR, methyl viologen  was added to serve as a redox mediator for FAD (GR) reduction. Experiments were again conducted in ultrasmall observation volumes containing a single GR molecule on average. Fluorescence was observed to decrease (increase) at reducing (oxidizing) potentials for MV due to the MV-mediated control of the GR redox state. The spectroelectrochemical response of GR to the enzyme substrate confirmed that GSSG promotes GR oxidation coupled to reduction of the enzyme cofactor.

 

The final scientific activity grew out of an NSF INTERN award, the goal of which was to explore the potential of NEAs to be efficient sensing architectures for diagnostic applications using affinity-based capture by antibodies or aptamers derivatized on intrapore electrodes. We used the detection of cytokines, in particular interleukin-6 (IL-6), a biomarker for pro-inflammatory behavior, as the test case. An IL-6 interdigitated electrode array sensor performance was assessed in buffer solution, as well as whole CSF and whole serum to study the versatility and potential to use the sensor in different operating environments. Sensing was performed via differential pulse voltammetry, in which the peak current was found to correlate with IL-6 concentration in buffer, CSF, and serum in the range 1 pg mL-1 - 1 ?g mL-1.

 

The broader impacts of this project were made by developing programs for teaching and research that span universities, in particular Indiana University, Purdue University, and Notre Dame and by creating new platforms for industry-university cooperation that can have substantial impact on economic development. The former was demonstrated by the formation of the Indiana Consortium for Analytical Science and Engineering (ICASE). Using ICASE as a platform, we worked to create an ecosystem for the chemical and biomolecular measurement sciences that address the specific needs of Indiana businesses, by providing opportunities for new company start-ups, by licensing technologies developed at the consortium partners to Indiana firms and by making available a highly trained and motivated professional workforce. We also worked to improve the climate for high-technology ventures within Indiana by working closely with public and private groups to make the case for measurement-science-based companies to invest in Indiana.


Last Modified: 02/23/2023
Modified by: Paul W Bohn
